awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: IRIS: A unified data access framework for the merging of compute-centric and data-centric storage
awd_abstract_narration:
As the boundary between High Performance Computing (HPC) and High-Performance Data Analytics (HPDA) continue to blur, the conventional compute-centric HPC and the newly emerged data-driven Big Data application are converging. HPC becomes more data-intensive. In the meantime, HPDA requires more computing power. MapReduce and Spark software environments are developed and are popular for HPDA. However, these software frameworks are not designed for HPC and not compatible with HPC storage subsystems. In this research, the design and development of a unified data access framework, named IRIS, is proposed for the integration of compute-centric and data-centric storage solutions. 
   
The intellectual merit of this research is three-fold. 1) Mapping of incompatible structures: Mapping a file to key-value pairs and vice versa efficiently is a challenging task. 2) Maintaining metadata information: Since IRIS is a unified storage layer, it needs to maintain compatibility with legacy codes. IRIS will address this challenge with tunable consistency, which need to be carefully studied for implementation and design choices. 3) Minimizing overhead and memory footprint of IRIS solutions: Mapping of incompatible structures can cause excessive memory usage; this will be addressed in this research.

This project is expected to have significant impact, including bridging data generation and data analysis processes; promoting collaboration between the model simulation and data analysis communities; and building a foundation element for next generation integrated storage systems. This research will create advanced solutions and technologies that will have direct impact on improving the efficiency of data access and management at scale. Since Big Data is a national strategic infrastructure for science, engineering, and industry, this research will advance a broad range of fields. It aims to make significant progress toward a unified storage access system. 

All data generated from this project will be stored in an electronic format and will be preserved on the server machines at the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT): http://cs.iit.edu/~scs/. The server machines have hot-copy backup disks for backing up the primary copy of all data. A secondary copy of all data will be kept on the server machines in the computer science department at IIT per semester basis. The data will be transferred to new storage devices every 2 years. All data will be retained within 3 years of the project completion date.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The IRIS project, funded by the National Science Foundation, aimed to revolutionize the integration of High-Performance Computing (HPC) and High-Performance Data Analytics (HPDA) systems. Traditional disparities in design philosophies and target applications between these two systems presented a significant challenge, as HPC systems prioritize strong data consistency while Big Data systems leverage data locality and often relax consistency requirements. The goal of IRIS was to bridge these differences through the development of a unified data access framework, facilitating seamless interoperability and integration of compute-centric and data-centric storage solutions. This endeavor was crucial for addressing the evolving needs of data-intensive HPC and HPDA applications across a spectrum of scientific and engineering domains.

Throughout its execution, the IRIS project successfully designed and developed the IRIS framework, a unified data access layer capable of integrating diverse storage solutions. This framework enabled applications to use compute-centric and data-centric storage systems efficiently and interchangeably, thereby optimizing data access and storage efficiency. One of the project's most significant achievements was the demonstrable improvement in I/O performance, which included up to a 12x speedup in specific scientific simulation workflows. Such enhancements directly contributed to accelerating research and discovery processes, underlining the project's substantial impact on advancing the state of knowledge in its principal disciplines.

Moreover, the project's outcomes extended beyond the realms of HPC and HPDA, impacting a broad array of other disciplines. For instance, in healthcare and medicine, IRIS's advancements could support more efficient genomic analysis and personalized medicine approaches. In environmental monitoring and climate science, the project's contributions could enable more accurate and faster processing of large-scale data sets for climate modeling and biodiversity studies. The project also had a profound impact on education, incorporating its findings into advanced computing courses and preparing students for future challenges in technology and data analytics.

The IRIS project produced a range of valuable outputs, including new storage interfaces and mappings, optimized I/O paths, and several software tools like Niobe, Symbios, HCL, and the DLIO benchmark suite. These products have been disseminated widely through publications, conference presentations, and open-source software releases, fostering a rich community of users and contributors.

In terms of community recognition, the IRIS generates two Best Paper Awards at prestigious ACM/IEEE conferences. In terms of technology transfer, the project laid the groundwork for future commercialization efforts and industry collaborations. Its open-source software tools are not just academic exercises but represent practical solutions that address real-world data management challenges in diverse computational environments.

The societal impacts of the IRIS project extend into enhancing data management across various sectors, potentially revolutionizing how data-intensive applications are deployed and operated in fields ranging from scientific research to commercial data analytics. By improving the efficiency and effectiveness of data-intensive computational tasks, IRIS contributes to the broader societal goal of fostering informed decision-making and innovation.

In conclusion, the IRIS project represents a great leap forward in integrating HPC and HPDA systems. Its outcomes not only advance scientific knowledge and technical capabilities but also promise broad societal benefits, from healthcare and environmental science to education and beyond. The project stands as a testament to the power of collaborative research and innovation in addressing some of the most pressing challenges at the intersection of computing and data analytics.
